questions.Q: The equation of a line passing through two points $$A$$ and $$B$$ is:
questions.E: The slope of a line passing through two points $$A=(x_1, y_1)$$ and $$B=(x_2, y_2)$$ is $$m=\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}=\frac{0.5-(-1.0)}{1.0-(-0.5)}=1.0$$. The equation of the line with slope $$m$$ and passing through the point $$(x_0,y_0)$$ is given by $$y-y_0=m(x-x_0)$$. Taking  $$(x_0,y_0)=(0,-0.5)$$ we have: $$y-(-0.5)=1(x-0)\Leftrightarrow y=-\frac{1}{2}+x$$

questions.Q: The equation of a line passing through two points $$A$$ and $$B$$ is:
questions.E: The slope of a line passing through two points $$A=(x_1, y_1)$$ and $$B=(x_2, y_2)$$ is $$m=\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}=\frac{-1.25-0.75}{1.0-(-1.0)}=-1.0$$. The equation of the line with slope $$m$$ and passing through the point $$(x_0,y_0)$$ is given by $$y-y_0=m(x-x_0)$$. Taking  $$(x_0,y_0)=(0,-0.25)$$ we have: $$y-(-0.25)=1(x-0)\Leftrightarrow y=-\frac{1}{4}-x$$

questions.Q: The average of the slopes of the lines displayed in the figure is:
questions.E: The slopes of the lines $$A$$ and $$B$$ are $$m_A=\frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}=\frac{2.0}{0.75}=\frac{8}{3}$$ and $$m_B=\frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}=-\frac{0.75}{0.75}=-1$$ respectively. Therefore, tha average is $$\frac{m_A+m_B}{2}=\frac{\frac{8}{3}-1}{2}=\frac{5}{6}$$

questions.Q: Given the equation of the line $$3x+2y=-5$$, its slope is:
questions.E: The equation $$3x+2y=-5 \Leftrightarrow y=-\frac{3}{2}x-\frac{5}{2}$$. So, the slope of the line is $$-\frac{3}{2}$$ and the y-intercept is $$-\frac{5}{2}$$

questions.Q: Given the equation of the line $$3x+4y=1$$, its slope is:
questions.E: The equation $$3x+4y=1 \Leftrightarrow y=-\frac{3}{4}x-\frac{1}{4}$$. So, the slope of the line is $$-\frac{3}{4}$$ and the y-intercept is $$\frac{1}{4}$$

questions.Q: The slope of a line perpendicular to a line whose equation is given by $$3x+2y=1$$ is:
questions.E: The equation $$3x+2y=1 \Leftrightarrow y=-\frac{3}{2}x-\frac{1}{2}$$. So, the slope of the line is $$m_1=-\frac{3}{2}$$. On the other hand, for two mutually perpendicular lines and slopes $$m_1$$ and $$m_2$$ respectively, it is true that $$m_1m_2=-1$$. Thus, $$m_2=-\frac{1}{m_1}=-\frac{1}{-\frac{3}{2}}=\frac{2}{3}$$

questions.Q: The point of intersection of the following lines $$3x+2y=-5$$ and $$5x+2y=-5$$ is:
questions.E: The linear equations $$3x+2y=-5$$ and $$5x+2y=-2$$ are equivalent to $$y=-\frac{3}{2}x-\frac{5}{2}$$ and $$y=-\frac{5}{2}x-1$$. The x-intercept occurs when $$-\frac{3}{2}x-\frac{5}{2}=-\frac{5}{2}x-1\therefore x=\frac{3}{2}\\$$ Plugging this value of $$x$$ in the first equation we have: $$y=-\frac{3}{2}(\frac{3}{2})-\frac{5}{2}=-4\small{\frac{3}{4}}\\$$ Thus, the two lines meet at $$(\frac{3}{2},-4\small{\frac{3}{4}})$$
